close_symbols: translation-unit included headers and feature-test macros (e.g. _GNU_SOURCE)
compiler command-line / predefined macro list (-std, compiler vendor/version, enabled builtin macros)
explanation:
For checking MISRA C rule about language extensions you must know whether the code uses compiler/implementation-specific extensions. Each listed symbol is needed for that determination:

- __linux__ and __GLIBC__: these are implementation-defined/predefined macros supplied by the compiler or C library. Their presence and use may constitute use of compiler/library-specific extensions; you need the exact definitions (or knowledge that they are predefined) to decide if their use violates the rule.

- mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_, mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_cpuset_getaffinity_, mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_sched_getaffinity_np_, mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count_w32_ (declarations/definitions): the target function only calls these wrappers. To be sure no language extensions are used you must inspect their prototypes/definitions to detect any compiler-specific extensions (e.g. __attribute__, __declspec, nonstandard calling conventions, inline asm, vendor-specific types, or other extension tokens) that would make the translation unit use language extensions.

- translation-unit included headers and feature-test macros (e.g. _GNU_SOURCE): headers or feature-test macros can enable nonstandard APIs or expose compiler extensions (e.g. GNU extensions). You need the included headers and any feature-test macros to see whether the compilation relies on extensions.

- compiler command-line / predefined macro list (compiler vendor/version and -std mode): whether an identifier or construct is an extension depends on the compiler and enabled language mode (gnu vs strict C). The compiler flags and the list of predefined macros let you determine if the observed macros/constructs are documented extensions for that compiler.

Provide these symbols (macro definitions, callee prototypes/definitions, TU includes, and compiler flags) to the next agent so it can conclusively determine whether any compiler/language extensions are used.
